results.title: The Little Colonel
results.creator_credit: David Butler, B G De Sylva Productions and Fox Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
After a blistery Southern Colonel (Lionel Barrymore) banishes his daughter (Evelyn Venable) for marrying a Northener (John Lodge), he refuses to see her even when she returns years later with her young daughter (Shirley Temple). As outspoken as her grandfather, the ingenious child turns on plenty of charm and wins his heart. Includes a remarkable tap dance/soft-shoe routine with the famous Bill “Mr Bojangles” Robinson. In a role she makes her own, Hattie McDaniel of “Gone with the wind” fame, plays Mammy. The original production was in black and white, with the final scene shot in technicolor, however this version has been computer colourised.

results.title: The Court-martial of Billy Mitchell
results.creator_credit: Otto Preminger, Milton Sperling and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: After World War One, Brigadier General Billy Mitchell, (Gary Cooper), forsees the deadly power and military importance of airplanes, previously used only by the US Army for reconnaissance. His superiors refuse to heed his advice, despite convincing evidence. When Mitchell persists in his campaign, he is called before a Court Martial and branded a traitor. Although General Duthrie, (Charles Bickford) attempts a cover-up at the trial, it becomes a media event, revealing how one man’s vision can shape history. This was the first screen appearance of Elizabeth Montgomery.

results.title: Can-can
results.creator_credit: Walter Lang, Jack Cummings and Suffolk-Cummings Productions
results.brief_description: It’s 1896 and the “naughty” Can-Can has been banned in Paris. That doesn’t stop a vivacious cafe owner, (Shirley MacLaine), from performing it anyway, much to the delight of her patrons. She’s been able to ignore the law because her clever lawyer, (Frank Sinatra), has a corrupt judge, (Maurice Chevalier), in his pocket. Their sweet setup abruptly changes when a new judge, (Louis Jourdan), decides to put a stop to this shocking behaviour. Little does he know, that the real fun and excitement is just beginning! Features three Cole Porter songs that were not in the original hit show, lavish sets, stunning costumes and plenty of high-stepping dance numbers. Like Paris in the summer, Can-Can sizzles!

results.title: Cool hand Luke
results.creator_credit: Stuart Rosenberg, Gordon Carroll, Jalem Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Paul Newman stars as “Cool Hand Luke”, the irreverent loner, sentenced to work on a chain gang for destroying parking meters. George Kennedy stars as the sadistic convict boss who tries to break Newman’s spirit by using an arsenal of punishments and torture such as ‘the box’; a windowless cubicle designed to drive an inmate insane. In one of his most memorable parts, Newman as Luke, will not allow himself to succumb to the arbitrary rules of captivity. Nevertheless, the audience is left with an impression of Luke as a victim to be pitied rather than scorned.

results.brief_description: The greatest space epic of all time reaches its unforgettable conclusion in 2010 - the year we make contact. While the Earth poises on the brink of nuclear self-destruction, a team of Russian amd American scientists, headed by Roy Scheider and Helen Mirren hurtle to a rendezvous with the abandoned Discovery spacecraft and its sole known survivor, the homicidal computer HAL. Their mission is to ‘awake’ HAL and unravel the puzzling skein of events that culminated in astronaut Dave Bowman’s last transmission, “My God, it’s full of stars!” seen at the end of 2001. This is an emotionally moving thriller in which the human drama takes its rightful place alongside the movie’s visual magic.

results.title: Patton
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Frank McCarthy and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: General Patton was the only Allied General truly feared by the Nazi’s. In this riveting portrait of one of the greatest military minds of the modern world, George C. Scott gives an Award winning performance. Patton designed his own uniforms, sported ivory-handled six-shooters, and believed he was a warrior in past lives. Outwitting Rommel in Africa, after D-Day he led his troops across Europe. Rebellious and brilliant, he struggled with his own volatile personality. Co-starring Karl Malden, screenplay by Francis Ford Coppola and Edmund H. North and winner of eight Academy Awards in 1970.

results.title: True stories
results.creator_credit: David Byrne, Gary Kurfist, True Stories Venture and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: David Byrne from the legendary band “Talking Heads” ponders life’s more trivial, but nevertheless vital questions. Why do hotdogs come in packets of 10, but buns do not? Featuring Byrne’s song-writing talents and the performance of “Talking Heads”, this film of episodic stories features some of the most amiable but offbeat characters imaginable.

results.title: Belle de Jour
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Betty Edmonds, Raymond Hakim, Robert Edmonds, Five Films and Paris Film
results.brief_description: Catherine Deneuve plays a beautiful young woman married to a rich young surgeon (Jean Sorel). Their life is a material success but the wife’s frigidity is a strain on the marriage. Plagued by masochistic sexual fantasies, she takes a part-time job in a brothel, hoping that by playing the part of Belle de Jour, the high class prostitute, she can overcome her dislike for sex. This is a savagely funny, and often a very cruel film, as it pulls apart the consumerist psyche of a bourgeois woman to reveal her as souless and empty of life. Stripped of her clothes, her jewellery, her status, she is a no-one. It is only as Belle de Jour that she can emotionally experience life. The movie moves back and forth from the casual filmwork of the brothel scenes to the surrealist dream sequences where Belle de Jour recieves the punishments she feels she deserves. Though often criticised as a misogynist film, it is not women who are the target of Bunuel’s satire, but the pretensions of wealth and status. Nor is the sexuality of men sacred for Bunuel as some of the funniest sequences deal with the absurdities of masculine desire. Co-starring Michel Piccoli and Genevieve Page. Based on the novel by Jospeh Kessel.

results.title: Girl of the Golden West
results.creator_credit: Robert Z Leonard, William Anthony McGuire and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Cowpokes from all around agree. Ain’t nobody like Mary, the tomboy they call “the girl.” She is equally at ease serving a slug of whisky as she is trilling a tune and when it comes to playing a hand of cards to save the neck of the man she loves, she does as any cowboy would, she cheats. Saddling up for this song-filled sagebrusher are Jeanette MacDonald as Mary, and Nelson Eddy as Ramerez, the gold-hearted desperado whom she loves. However, Sheriff Rance (Walter Pidgeon) turns the twosome into a triangle. He’s got an eye for Mary and nothing would please him more than to hold a hanging for Ramerez! Sit back, grab a cuppa and get ready to enjoy a rip-snorting good time!

results.title: Breakfast at Tiffany's
results.creator_credit: Blake Edwards, Martin Jurow, Richard Shepherd and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Audrey Hephurn stars as Holly Golightly in the film based on the short story by Truman Capote. Holly’s almost frosty sophistication is only a veneer. Hepburn convey’s Holly’s underlying fragility with poignance and sympathy. George Peppard, as Paul the writer, like Holly is searching to find a place amongst the “fleshpots” and “rats” of New York. As their love blossoms, Paul must come to terms with the fact that Holly is a girl on the run, not only from the past, but from herself. New York, Tiffany’s, Givenchy’s stunning wardrobe for Hepburn, the magical music of Henry Mancini and Johnny Mercer’s song “Moon River”, help make this film a cinema classic. Mickey Rooney as Holly’s slightly deranged Japanese landlord, delights in a hilarious comic cameo.
